title.value: GraphCG: Unsupervised Discovery of Steerable Factors in Graphs
title.justification: This is the title of the research paper.
title.quote: GraphCG: Unsupervised Discovery of Steerable Factors in Graphs

extractions.description: This paper introduces GraphCG, an unsupervised method for discovering steerable factors in graph data. The method is model-agnostic and task-agnostic and leverages mutual information maximization to identify semantic directions in the graph data's latent space. The paper evaluates the method on molecular graphs and point clouds, demonstrating its effectiveness in discovering meaningful semantic directions.

type.justification: The paper conducts experiments on molecular graphs and point clouds to evaluate the effectiveness of their proposed method, GraphCG, for discovering steerable factors.
type.quote: We conduct experiments on two types of graph data, molecular graphs and point clouds. Both the quantitative and qualitative results show the effectiveness of GraphCG for discovering steerable factors.

name.justification: The paper focuses on deep generative models specifically tailored for graph data, aiming to uncover steerable factors within this data.
name.quote: Yet, much less investigation has been carried out on understanding the learned latent space of deep graph generative models.

name.justification: GraphCG is an unsupervised method for discovering steerable factors in graph data.
name.quote: we then propose an unsupervised method called GraphCG, which is model-agnostic and task-agnostic for discovering steerable factors in graph data.

name.justification: The method involves discovering steerable directions in the latent space of graph data.
name.quote: we assume that maximizing the MI between edited data points with different editing conditions (directions and step sizes) can maximize the shared information within each semantic direction and step size, while diversifying the semantic information among different conditions.

name.justification: GraphCG is the primary model proposed in this paper for discovering steerable factors in graph data.
name.quote: we then propose an unsupervised method called GraphCG, which is model-agnostic and task-agnostic for discovering steerable factors in graph data.

is_contributed.justification: GraphCG is introduced and evaluated in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: we then propose an unsupervised method called GraphCG, which is model-agnostic and task-agnostic for discovering steerable factors in graph data.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed to perform experiments on molecular graphs and point clouds.
is_executed.quote: We conduct experiments on two types of graph data, molecular graphs and point clouds. Both the quantitative and qualitative results show the effectiveness of GraphCG for discovering steerable factors.

is_compared.justification: GraphCG is compared with other methods in terms of its effectiveness in discovering steerable factors.
is_compared.quote: we propose a novel evaluation metric called sequence monotonic ratio (SMR) to measure the output sequences. We summarize our contributions as follows: (1) We conduct an empirical study on the disentanglement property of three pretrained deep generative models (DGMs) on two types of graph data, molecular graphs and point clouds. We find that the latent space of these pretrained graph DGMs is not perfectly disentangled. (2) We propose a model-agnostic and task-agnostic method called GraphCG for the unsupervised graph controllable generation. GraphCG aims at learning the semantic directions by maximizing their corresponding mutual information, and its outputs are sequences of graphs. (3) We evaluate the proposed methods on two types of graph data, molecular graphs and point clouds. The experimental results show the clear improvement (up to 3 times better in SMC) over the baselines.

referenced_paper_title.justification: GraphCG is the model proposed in this paper, so it does not reference another paper for its introduction.

name.justification: ZINC250K is used in experiments for evaluating the effectiveness of GraphCG on molecular graphs.
name.quote: MoFlow and HierVAE are for molecular graphs, PointFlow is for point clouds. Dataset: ZINC250k

referenced_paper_title.value: Irwin, J. J., & Shoichet, B. K. (2005). ZINC—a free database of commercially available compounds for virtual screening. Journal of chemical information and modeling, 45(1), 177-182.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The ZINC250K dataset is referenced in the context of its use in molecular graph experiments.

name.justification: ChEMBL is used in experiments for evaluating the effectiveness of GraphCG on molecular graphs.

referenced_paper_title.value: Mendez, D., Gaulton, A., Bento, A. P., Chambers, J., De Veij, M., Félix, E., ... & Hersey, A. (2019). ChEMBL: towards direct deposition of bioassay data. Nucleic acids research, 47(D1), D930-D940.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The ChEMBL dataset is referenced in the context of its use in molecular graph experiments.

name.justification: ShapeNet is used in experiments for evaluating the effectiveness of GraphCG on point clouds.
name.quote: we consider PointFlow pretrained on three datasets in ShapeNet [2]: Airplane, Car, and Chair.

referenced_paper_title.value: Chang, A. X., Funkhouser, T., Guibas, L., Hanrahan, P., Huang, Q., ... & Nießner, M. (2015). ShapeNet: An information-rich 3D model repository. arXiv preprint arXiv:1512.03012.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The ShapeNet dataset is referenced in the context of its use in point cloud experiments.

name.justification: RDKit is used for molecular graph processing.
name.quote: We use RDKit [29] to extract 9 most distinguishable fragments as steerable factors for disentanglement measurement.

referenced_paper_title.value: Landrum, G., et al. (2013). RDKit: Open-source cheminformatics; 2013.
referenced_paper_title.justification: RDKit is used in the context of extracting functional groups in molecular graphs for evaluating disentanglement.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Landrum, G., et al. (2013). RDKit: Open-source cheminformatics; 2013.

name.justification: PCL is used for point cloud processing.
name.quote: For point clouds, we use PCL tool [44] to extract 75 VFH descriptors [45] as steerable factors, which depict the geometries and viewpoints accordingly.

referenced_paper_title.value: Rusu, R. B., & Cousins, S. (2011). 3D is here: Point Cloud Library (PCL). In 2011 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (pp. 1-4). IEEE.
